text: - Hi, I'm Mark Greville.
I'm the VP of Architecture at Workhuman.
So, we've been on an incredible journey
over the last four years really.
When I joined Workhuman,
we were fully on premise,
and we are on a journey.
At the moment, we were in the cloud,
we have elastic scale.

We've been on a journey
in a number of areas,
but particularly in data.
For data, when I joined as well,
one of the decisions we made

was that we needed to
consolidate all of our data
into a single data platform.

Whereas before, we had
disparate data sources,
all over the company.
And one of the reasons for this is,

we couldn't anticipate
what we may need to do
with the data in future,
but we knew we didn't want to lose it,
and we had to be able to have a platform
that allows to elastically scale,

so that we could give
customers what they needed,

we could give internal
employees what they needed,
and we could also provide what was needed
for the product development as well.
We had a number of challenges.

One of them was telling
the story, explaining why,
the why we needed to do this,

and to do that, we used
the word imagine a lot,

and went around to a lot
of people across Workhuman,
and talked about imagining what
the future could look like
if we had access to this data.
Imagine what decisions we could make

if people had various
insights into the data.

And that really was one of
the core building blocks
to allow us to begin the journey,

and once that value was there
and in place for everybody,
well then the groundswell

of people being interested
in data became overwhelming,
and all of a sudden,

we had everybody who
wanted to get on board

with this transformational
data platform that we had.
It had a major impact as well
on what we were able to do for customers.

Customers now really need
access to a lot of data,

and in some cases, have to
have access to a lot of data.

So, we were also able to use
the capabilities we built in,
in conjunction with AWS,

to give access to data
through a series of data APIs,

and a reporting capability
to allow customers themselves

to build their own reports
on top of our data,
and take our data and build reports
in their own analytics platforms.

I'm not sure the journey
here will ever end.
In fact, I think we see all the time

that technology advances and
then the business catches up,

and sometimes businesses advance
and technology catches up.
So, we're always going to be in this cycle
of making tech advances,
analyzing the business capabilities,
analyzing what's happening on that side,

and then making further
technology advances.

Certainly, generative AI is
very frothy at the moment,
but AI in general is massively important.
But of course, AI can't really work

unless there's a very solid
data foundation underneath it,
and I think this is something
that people need to do more work on is,
making sure the foundations are solid
with regards to data platform.
The AI can be built on top of that,
and then UX is the final piece.
